OperationalDetails.title: Basic Overview
OperationalDetails.description: The Solid Fuel Generator burns coal, biomass, or other solid fuels to produce electricity.

OperationalDetails.title: Fuel Types
OperationalDetails.description: Different fuels have different burn rates and efficiency:

children.title: Coal
children.description: Primary fuel source, obtained from mining coal ore.

children.title: Charcoal
children.description: Made by processing wood in a furnace.

children.title: Biomass
children.description: Renewable fuel from plants.

OperationalDetails.title: Setup Guide
OperationalDetails.description: Follow these steps to set up your generator:
steps: Place the Solid Fuel Generator on a solid surface
Connect power cables to the generator
Ensure the room has oxygen (required for combustion)
Insert fuel into the generator slot
Set the generator to ON using logic or manual switch

OperationalDetails.title: Troubleshooting
OperationalDetails.description: Common issues and solutions:

children.title: Generator Won't Start
items: Verify oxygen level in room (needs O2 for combustion)

slots.name: Battery
slots.description: Powers all robot operations. Drains 5W idle + 10WMotorPower when moving + 2.5W per IC10 execution cycle.

slots.name: ProgrammableChip
slots.description: IC10 chip for automation. Inserting resets Mode to 0 and TargetX/Y/Z to 0.

None.description: Idle state. Robot brakes and awaits commands. Target cleared, no movement.

Follow.description: Follows nearest human player. Uses direct line movement (no pathfinding). Applies stuck detection.

MoveToTarget.description: Moves directly toward TargetX/Y/Z coordinates. No pathfinding - will get stuck on obstacles. Reverts to Mode 0 on arrival.

Roam.description: Autonomous mining mode. Wanders randomly while searching for ore within 32 blocks. Auto-mines when ore found. Switches to Mode 6 when storage full.

Unload.description: Searches for Chute Inlet or Bin within 3 meters. Deposits one ore stack every 3 seconds. Returns to Mode 0 when empty or no input found.

PathToTarget.description: Uses A* pathfinding to navigate to TargetX/Y/Z. Can navigate around obstacles and through rooms. Returns to Mode 0 when path completed or fails.

StorageFull.description: Automatic mode set when all 8 ore slots are occupied. Robot stops operations until storage is cleared. Set Mode to 4 (Unload) to deposit.

OperationalDetails.title: Operating Modes
OperationalDetails.description: AIMeE has 7 operating modes controlled by the Mode logic variable:

children.title: Mode 0 - None (Idle)
children.description: Default idle state. The robot applies brakes and waits for commands.
items: Set after completing MoveToTarget, PathToTarget, or Unload operations

children.title: Mode 1 - Follow
children.description: Robot follows the nearest human player using direct line-of-sight movement.

children.title: Mode 2 - MoveToTarget
children.description: Direct movement to TargetX/Y/Z coordinates without pathfinding.
items: Moves in straight line toward target
Reverts to Mode 0 when within 1m of target

children.title: Mode 3 - Roam (Autonomous Mining)
children.description: Fully autonomous mining mode. Wanders, discovers ore, and mines automatically.
items: Wanders with random steering changes every 1-3 seconds
Searches for ore within 32 blocks horizontal, 2 blocks deep
Automatically navigates to and mines discovered ore
Triggers ore vein generation as it moves (just like player exploration)
Reverses for 5 seconds when hitting terrain obstacles
Auto-switches to Mode 6 (StorageFull) when all slots occupied

children.title: Mode 4 - Unload
children.description: Deposits stored ore into nearby Chute Inlets or Bins.
items: Searches for IRobotInput devices within 3 meters
Deposits one ore stack every 3 seconds
Returns to Mode 0 when storage is empty
Returns to Mode 0 if no valid input device found

children.title: Mode 5 - PathToTarget
children.description: Intelligent pathfinding to TargetX/Y/Z using A* algorithm.
items: Can navigate around obstacles and through rooms
Path recalculates if stuck for 5 seconds
May hop slightly when path requires height changes
Returns to Mode 0 when destination reached or path fails

children.title: Mode 6 - StorageFull
children.description: Automatic state set when all 8 ore storage slots are occupied.
items: Cannot be manually set via IC10
Automatically triggered by Roam mode when full
Set Mode to 4 (Unload) to deposit ore
Or manually remove ore to continue

OperationalDetails.title: IC10 Programming
OperationalDetails.description: AIMeE executes IC10 programs from an inserted ProgrammableChip:

children.title: Execution Details
children.description: How the IC10 chip executes on AIMeE:
items: Costs 2.5W per execution cycle (deducted from battery)
Only executes when: On=1, Powered, has chip, no compilation errors
Pauses execution when game is paused

children.title: Chip Reset Behavior
children.description: When inserting a new ProgrammableChip, AIMeE automatically resets:
items: TargetX, TargetY, TargetZ are set to 0
Chip program counter is reset to line 0
Any existing path data is cleared

children.title: Device Addressing
children.description: How to reference the robot and its slots in IC10:
items: Use 'db' to reference AIMeE herself (d0 equivalent)

OperationalDetails.title: Power Management
OperationalDetails.description: AIMeE is battery-powered with multiple consumption sources:

children.title: Power Consumption
children.description: Power draw varies based on activity:
items: IC10 Execution: 2.5W per tick when program runs
Motor Power: 10W  CurrentMotorPower when wheels turning
Total moving: Approximately 15-25W depending on speed

children.title: Battery Indicator
children.description: The Power logic variable shows 5 charge levels:

OperationalDetails.title: Stuck Detection & Recovery
OperationalDetails.description: AIMeE has built-in stuck detection for movement modes:
items: Checks position every 60 seconds while moving
If moved less than 0.1 meters in 60 seconds, considered stuck
Recovery: Teleports slightly in random direction
Active in modes: Follow (1), MoveToTarget (2), Roam (3), PathToTarget (5)
PathToTarget has additional 5-second path recalculation on stuck

OperationalDetails.title: Mining System (Roam Mode)
OperationalDetails.description: How AIMeE discovers and mines ore in Roam mode:

children.title: Ore Detection
children.description: Ore search parameters:
items: Vertical search depth: 2 blocks below surface
Uses same ore vein generation as player exploration
Reading MineablesInVicinity triggers ore vein generation

children.title: Mining Process
children.description: What happens when ore is found:
items: Navigates to within 2 meters of ore node
Ore is automatically added to first available slot
Stacks with existing ore of same type
Sets Mode to 6 (StorageFull) when all 8 slots filled

OperationalDetails.title: Tips & Best Practices
OperationalDetails.description: Recommendations for effective AIMeE operation:
items: Use PathToTarget (Mode 5) in bases, MoveToTarget (Mode 2) outdoors
Position Chute Inlets within 3m of AIMeE's patrol area for Unload
Monitor battery charge - robot stops all operations when empty
Reading MineablesInVicinity generates ore veins - useful for exploration
TargetX/Y/Z persist through mode changes until new chip inserted

OperationalDetails.title: Heat Pump Operation
OperationalDetails.description: The Air Conditioner is a heat pump that moves thermal energy between its 100L internal volume and the waste output. It heats or cools the internal atmosphere toward the Setting temperature (default 293.15K / 20C).

OperationalDetails.title: Idle Power Draw
OperationalDetails.description: When powered on but not actively heating/cooling, draws 345W idle power. Maximum power consumption is 6000W when operating at full capacity.

OperationalDetails.title: Efficiency Factors
OperationalDetails.description: Three factors affect efficiency: (1) Temperature Differential - larger differences between current and target temp reduce efficiency. (2) Operational Temperature - extreme temps reduce efficiency. (3) Pressure Efficiency - optimal at ~100kPa, reduced at very low or very high pressures.

OperationalDetails.title: Connections
OperationalDetails.description: Input: Takes gas from pipe network. Output: Returns conditioned gas. Output2 (Waste): Outputs waste heat/cold - connect this to space or a heat exchanger to dissipate.

OperationalDetails.title: Heat Exchange
OperationalDetails.description: Energy transferred = (TargetTemp - CurrentTemp)  HeatCapacity  EfficiencyFactors. The waste output receives the opposite thermal load - if cooling input, waste heats up; if heating input, waste cools down.

OperationalDetails.title: Phase Change: Gas to Liquid
OperationalDetails.description: Converts gases into their liquid form when temperature is below the gas's condensation point. Gas enters via Pipe Input, liquid exits via Liquid Output.

OperationalDetails.title: Liquid Drain Rate
OperationalDetails.description: Drains liquid at 99% (0.99) ratio per tick. This high drain rate prevents liquid buildup and ensures continuous operation.

OperationalDetails.title: Regulated Gas Intake
OperationalDetails.description: Takes in gas regulated by the OutputSetting pressure value. The Setting controls target intake pressure from the pipe network.

OperationalDetails.title: 200L Internal Volume
OperationalDetails.description: Same as Evaporation Chamber - 200L internal volume with 6000 max setting. Has heat exchanger area of 10 units for thermal calculations.

OperationalDetails.title: Temperature Requirements
OperationalDetails.description: Condensation requires gas to be cooled below its phase transition temperature. Connect to cooling system or cold environment. Heat is released during condensation.

OperationalDetails.title: Three Operating Modes
OperationalDetails.description: Mode 0 (Default): Reports angle between sensor's forward direction and sun. Mode 1 (Horizontal): Reports horizontal azimuth angle. Mode 2 (Vertical): Reports vertical elevation angle.

OperationalDetails.title: Light Detection
OperationalDetails.description: HasLight property (read via Activate) returns 1 when sensor detects direct sunlight, 0 when in shadow. Used for automatic lighting control via linked motherboards.

OperationalDetails.title: Solar Tracking Data
OperationalDetails.description: Horizontal: Azimuth angle to sun (-180 to 180). Vertical: Elevation angle to sun. SolarAngle: Angle between sensor forward and sun direction. Use for solar panel tracking.

OperationalDetails.title: Solar Irradiance
OperationalDetails.description: Returns current solar power (W/m) accounting for weather events. Weather storms reduce this value via SolarRatio multiplier. Returns 0 when not in sunlight.

OperationalDetails.title: Motherboard Integration
OperationalDetails.description: Can link to Circuitboards via RemoteToggle. When light state changes (HasLight), triggers linked boards if their parent computer is powered.

OperationalDetails.title: Phase Change: Liquid to Gas
OperationalDetails.description: Converts liquid inputs into their gaseous form. Liquid enters via the Liquid Input connection and exits as gas through the Pipe Output.

OperationalDetails.title: Liquid Intake Rate
OperationalDetails.description: Accepts up to 0.25L of liquid per game tick. The device tries to maintain liquid volume at 10% of its internal capacity for optimal operation.

OperationalDetails.title: Heat Connection
OperationalDetails.description: Has a heat exchanger connection for thermal energy transfer. The evaporation process requires energy - connect to a heat source or the device will cool down during operation.

OperationalDetails.title: 200L Internal Volume
OperationalDetails.description: The chamber has 200L internal volume. Setting controls the output pressure target (max 6000 kPa). The heat exchanger area is 10 units for thermal calculations.

Setting.description: Target flow rate from liquid to gas.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Inward.description: Filters gases from the input pipe network.

Outward.description: Outputs filtered gases to the pipe network.

OperationalDetails.title: Gas Filter Slots
OperationalDetails.description: Accepts Gas Filter cartridges in its slots. Each filter type (Oxygen, Nitrogen, CO2, Pollutant, Volatiles, Water, N2O) captures its specific gas type. Filtered gas exits via the 'Filtered' output.

OperationalDetails.title: Three-Way Connection
OperationalDetails.description: Input: Mixed gas enters. Filtered Output: Gas matching filter types exits here. Unfiltered Output: Gases NOT matching any filter exit here. This allows selective gas separation.

OperationalDetails.title: Power Consumption
OperationalDetails.description: Uses 100W per atmosphere (per mole processed). Power consumption scales with how much gas flows through the device.

OperationalDetails.title: Minimum Filter Ratio
OperationalDetails.description: Has a MinimumRatioToFilterAll threshold of 0.001 (0.1%). Gases below this ratio may not be fully captured by filters.

OperationalDetails.title: IC Slot
OperationalDetails.description: Includes a ProgrammableChip slot for automated logic control. Use IC10 to dynamically control filtration based on gas ratios or pressures.

Mode.description: Filtration mode. 0 = Filter all, 1 = Filter gases, 2 = Filter liquids.

OperationalDetails.title: Overview
OperationalDetails.description: The Furnace smelts ores into ingots using combustion. Load ores and fuel (ice), close the door, then activate to ignite. The burning volatiles create the heat and pressure needed for smelting.

OperationalDetails.title: Steel Smelting (Most Common Use)
OperationalDetails.description: Ores: Iron Ore (Fe) + Coal Ore in 3:1 ratio. Standard batch: 15 Iron + 5 Coal = 5 Steel ingots. Requires temperature above 900K (627C) and pressure above ~100 kPa (can go very high, 100+ MPa is fine).

OperationalDetails.title: Fuel Recipe
OperationalDetails.description: Use Oxite + Volatiles ice to create combustion. Cold planet ratio: 8 Volatiles + 4 Oxite (typical for Europa/Moon). On Vulcan/Venus, less ice needed as ambient heat helps. More volatiles = more heat and pressure.

OperationalDetails.title: Smelting Process
OperationalDetails.description: 1) Load iron ore and coal (3:1 ratio) into furnace. /n2) Add volatiles ice (fuel) and oxite ice (oxidizer). 3) Close the furnace door. 4) Activate - volatiles burn with oxygen, creating heat. 5) Wait for Mode=1 or temperature 900K+. 6) Smelting completes automatically when conditions are met.

OperationalDetails.title: Common Problems
OperationalDetails.description: Won't activate: Ensure door is closed and you have both fuel (volatiles) and oxidizer (oxite). Mode=0: Invalid recipe or conditions not met - check ore ratios and wait for temp/pressure. No output: Ingots appear in export slot - check ExportCount via logic or open door after completion.

OperationalDetails.title: Logic Automation
OperationalDetails.description: Read Temperature to track smelting progress. Mode=1 means ready to smelt, Mode=0 means conditions not met. Ratio shows smelting progress (0 to 1). Use ExportCount > 0 to trigger chute/arm pickup.

OperationalDetails.title: Tips
OperationalDetails.description: The furnace can handle extreme pressures - don't fear high MPa readings. On cold planets (Europa), you need more fuel ice for heat. On hot planets (Vulcan), ambient temperature helps - use less ice. Smelting releases gases that increase pressure - this is normal. Lock the furnace via logic to prevent accidental opening mid-smelt.

Mode0.description: Smelting mode - combines multiple ore types into alloys. Requires correct ratios and temperature.

Mode1.description: Refining mode - purifies single ore type into pure ingots. Higher temperature yields better purity.

OperationalDetails.description: Very slow movement with base speed of 0.002. Horizontal movement slows down at higher vertical angles. Rotation tolerance is extremely precise at 0.00001 degrees.

OperationalDetails.title: Rotation Range
OperationalDetails.description: 360 horizontal rotation (-180 to 180), 90 vertical range (0 to 90). Write Horizontal and Vertical logic values to aim the dish.

OperationalDetails.title: Power Requirements
OperationalDetails.description: Setting controls wattage output. Higher power increases effective range and signal strength. Use MinimumWattsToContact to check if enough power is reaching the target.

OperationalDetails.title: Signal Strength vs Angle
OperationalDetails.description: Narrower beam = more power: 2 beam = 100% efficiency, 5 = 90%, 22.5 = 10%, 45 = 5%, 90 = 1%, 180 = 0.1%. Tighter focus dramatically increases effective range.

OperationalDetails.title: Contact Acquisition
OperationalDetails.description: Scans for trader contacts within its field of view. Use TargetPadIndex to select which landing pad traders should use. WattsReachingContact shows current signal strength at target.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

OperationalDetails.title: Internal Atmosphere
OperationalDetails.description: Has a 500L internal atmosphere storage. Gas is pumped between internal storage and external environment (or docked PassiveVent pipe network). Pressure gauges show internal atmosphere state.

OperationalDetails.title: Vent Direction Mode
OperationalDetails.description: Mode controls direction: 0=Outward (pump gas from internal to external), 1=Inward (pump gas from external to internal). PressureExternal/PressureInternal set target pressure thresholds.

OperationalDetails.title: Gas Filter Support
OperationalDetails.description: Install a Gas Filter in slot 0 to selectively pump gases. Filter type determines which gas passes through. Empty or missing filter pumps all gases.

OperationalDetails.title: PassiveVent Docking
OperationalDetails.description: When extended over a PassiveVent, the arm connects to the vent's pipe network for gas transfer. Without a docked vent, gas transfers to/from the world atmosphere at the arm position.

OperationalDetails.title: Over-Pressure Protection
OperationalDetails.description: If pressure differential exceeds ~600 atm (60.6 MPa), the device takes damage. Sustained over-pressure for more than 5 ticks deals 5 brute damage per tick.

OperationalDetails.title: Atmospheric Logic Reads
OperationalDetails.description: Supports all atmospheric logic reads (PressureInput, TemperatureInput, RatioOxygenInput, etc.) reading from the arm position or docked vent. CombustionInput returns 1 if atmosphere is inflamed.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

OperationalDetails.title: Rail Junction Point
OperationalDetails.description: Serves as a bypass junction on robotic arm rail networks. Arms can be diverted into the bypass position when the bypass is opened. Each bypass is assigned a JunctionIndex in the network.

OperationalDetails.title: Open/Close Control
OperationalDetails.description: Write Open=1 to open the bypass allowing an arm to dock. Open=0 closes the bypass. CanOpen/CanClose check if operations are valid (requires Power, OnOff, and no arm blocking).

OperationalDetails.title: Docking Arms
OperationalDetails.description: When a robotic arm activates while stopped at this bypass position, it will dock into the bypass. This allows arms to exit the main rail loop for loading/unloading operations.

OperationalDetails.title: Network Integration
OperationalDetails.description: The bypass connects to rail nodes and tracks junction index within the network. The info screen displays current open/closed state. Must be powered and on to operate.

Extended.description: Returns 1 if the robotic arm is extended.

Open.description: Read/write state for cargo loading. Write 1 to open/load, 0 to close.

Setting.description: Configurable setting for the dock operation. Specific usage depends on dock mode.

Activate.description: Write 1 to trigger the dock's primary action.

PositionX.description: X-axis position of the robotic arm.

TargetSlotIndex.description: Read/write the target slot index for cargo operations.

TargetPrefabHash.description: The prefab hash of the target item/structure the dock is interacting with.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID hash for this device.

OperationalDetails.title: Slot Manipulation
OperationalDetails.description: The Cargo arm has a hand slot and targets other devices' slots. TargetSlotIndex (0-50) selects which slot to interact with on the target device below the arm.

OperationalDetails.title: Contextual Actions
OperationalDetails.description: When activated and extended: if hand is empty, picks up from target slot; if hand has item and target slot is empty, places item; if both occupied and slot is swappable, swaps items.

OperationalDetails.title: Target Detection
OperationalDetails.description: TargetPrefabHash returns the prefab hash of whatever device is at the arm's current position. Only interacts with accessible slots (not Plant slots, locked slots, or hidden slots).

OperationalDetails.title: Slot Index Control
OperationalDetails.description: Use Button4/Button5 to increment/decrement TargetSlotIndex manually, or write via logic. The dial knob on the device shows current index position.

OperationalDetails.title: Proxy Slot Access
OperationalDetails.description: Supports IProxySlot interface - slot 255 represents the target device's slot, allowing external systems to interact with whatever the arm is targeting.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Setting.description: Device-specific setting value.

Idle.description: 1 if arm is idle, 0 if active.

Extended.description: 1 if arm is extended/lowered, 0 if retracted.

Activate.description: Trigger to move arm off main rail into bypass position.

Quantity.description: Number of items in storage slots.

PositionX.description: X position of arm along rail network.

Error.description: Error state indicator.

OperationalDetails.title: Bulk Item Storage
OperationalDetails.description: Has 20 internal storage slots for collecting or ejecting items. Ratio returns fill percentage (0.0 to 1.0). Quantity returns exact item count (0-20).

OperationalDetails.title: Collection Mode
OperationalDetails.description: Mode=0 (Inward): Arm applies magnetic/gravity force to pull nearby items toward the collection point. Items within ~1m are ingested into storage slots.

OperationalDetails.title: Ejection Mode
OperationalDetails.description: Mode=1 (Outward): Arm ejects items from storage at random intervals (0.2-0.4s between ejections). Items are spawned at the arm end position with random rotation.

OperationalDetails.title: Chute Integration
OperationalDetails.description: Can interact with ChuteBin/ChuteInlet (outward mode deposits items) and ChuteExportBin (inward mode collects items when open). Auto-retracts when full (inward) or empty (outward).

OperationalDetails.title: Display State
OperationalDetails.description: The arm display changes based on fill level: Off (unpowered), then 1-4 states showing fill progress. Changes at slots 5, 12, and 19 filled.

OperationalDetails.title: Physics Collection
OperationalDetails.description: In inward mode, items within ~3m range have physics forces applied pulling them toward the collector. Force scales with distance (300-600N based on proximity).

Error.description: Returns 1 if device has error (no power, no robot docked, etc).

Activate.description: Triggers docked robot to perform action.

Setting.description: Action setting parameter for docked robot.

Idle.description: Returns 1 if docked robot is idle/not performing action.

Extended.description: Returns 1 if robotic arm is extended.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

TargetSlotIndex.description: Slot index of target in hopper.

OperationalDetails.title: Plant Automation
OperationalDetails.description: Specialized arm for hydroponics. Has a hand slot and extra slot (hopper) for seeds/produce. Interacts with HydroponicTrays and devices implementing IHarvestable.

OperationalDetails.title: Hand Occupied Actions
OperationalDetails.description: With plant/seed in hand: plants into empty tray. With fertilizer: adds to fertilizer slot. With produce: harvests if plant is mature and stacks if compatible.

OperationalDetails.title: Hand Empty Actions
OperationalDetails.description: If plant is mature/seeding: harvests produce to hand slot. If plant is dead/immature: destroys plant. If only fertilizer present: destroys fertilizer.

OperationalDetails.title: Face Display
OperationalDetails.description: The arm has a face display showing plant status: Idle (off/no plant), Happy (healthy growing plant), UnHappy (dehydrated/bad gas), Dead (plant died).

OperationalDetails.title: Chute Integration
OperationalDetails.description: Can deposit items into ChuteBin when open, or pick up items from ChuteExportBin. The extra slot serves as a buffer for harvested items.

OperationalDetails.title: Plant Logic Reads
OperationalDetails.description: Supports plant slot logic reads on proxy slot (255): Efficiency, Health, Growth, Mature, Seeding, MaturityRatio, SeedingRatio, HarvestedHash for the target tray's plant.

OperationalDetails.title: Memory Stack
OperationalDetails.description: Contains 32 instruction slots for filtering rules. Each instruction uses a 64-bit format with the opcode in the first 8 bits. Use the Memory Programmer to write instructions.

OperationalDetails.title: Filter Criteria
OperationalDetails.description: Items can be filtered by: PrefabHash (exact match or not-equals), SortingClass (with comparison operators), SlotType (with comparison operators), or Quantity (with comparison operators). Comparison operators: 0=Equals, 1=Greater, 2=Less, 3=NotEquals.

OperationalDetails.title: Logic Modes
OperationalDetails.description: Mode 0 (Any): Item passes to Export2 if ANY filter matches. Mode 1 (All): Item passes to Export2 only if ALL filters match. Mode 2 (None): Item passes to Export2 only if NO filters match. Non-matching items go to Export1.

OperationalDetails.title: Count Limiter Instruction
OperationalDetails.description: The LimitNextExecutionByCount instruction limits how many items the NEXT filter instruction will match. The count decrements with each match. Useful for sorting exact quantities.

OperationalDetails.title: Slot Layout
OperationalDetails.description: Slot 0 (Import): Items enter here. Slot 1 (Export - LEFT side): Non-matching items exit here. Slot 2 (Export2 - RIGHT side): Matching items exit here. Slot 3 (Chip): Accepts IC10 programmable chip for automation. When facing the export slots: Export is on the LEFT, Export2 is on the RIGHT.

OperationalDetails.title: Rail Network Door
OperationalDetails.description: A powered door designed for linear rail networks. Allows robotic arms to pass through when open. Integrates with the rail junction system.

OperationalDetails.title: Open/Close State
OperationalDetails.description: Write Open=1 to open the door, Open=0 to close. The door must be powered to operate. Unpowered doors remain in their current state.

OperationalDetails.title: Power Requirements
OperationalDetails.description: Requires 10W of power to operate. Power state can be read via Power logic. RequiredPower returns the power draw.

NameHash.description: Hash of the device's custom name if set.

Idle.description: Returns 1 if device is idle.

Setting.description: Device-specific setting value. Check source code for usage.

Error.description: Error state code. 0=No error. Check source code for error codes.

PrefabHash.description: Unique hash identifier for the device prefab.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID for this specific device instance.

OperationalDetails.title: Junction-Based Movement
OperationalDetails.description: The arm moves along a rail network between junction points. Setting controls the target junction index (TargetJunctionIndex). PositionX returns current junction index. Supports looping networks.

OperationalDetails.title: Arm States
OperationalDetails.description: ArmState cycles: Up (idle)  AnimatingDown  Down (interacting)  AnimatingUp  Up. Extended returns 1 when arm is Down. Idle returns 1 when arm is Up and not moving.

OperationalDetails.title: Obstruction Detection
OperationalDetails.description: The arm checks for collisions via overlap box detection. Error state (1) indicates obstruction. Arm won't move while obstructed. IsFaceBlocked prevents arm extension if structure blocks the path.

OperationalDetails.title: Starting Dock
OperationalDetails.description: One dock per network is the Starting Dock (affects junction index offset). Use the dedicated button to set which dock is the starting point for the rail network.

OperationalDetails.title: Bypass Points
OperationalDetails.description: Docks can have bypass points - the arm can 'dock' at another device along the rail. Open logic controls bypass state. CanOpen/CanClose check if bypass operations are valid.

OperationalDetails.title: Contextual Actions
OperationalDetails.description: When Activate triggers and arm extends, it performs contextual actions via RoboticArmActionHelper based on what's in the arm slot and what's below the arm position.

OperationalDetails.title: Memory Stack for Trading
OperationalDetails.description: Contains a 32-slot LogicStack for trader data queries. Use WriteTraderData, WriteTraderBuyData, and WriteTraderSellData instructions to interact with traders.

OperationalDetails.title: Dish Movement
OperationalDetails.description: 360 horizontal rotation, 90 vertical range. Medium speed dish - faster than Large but slower than Small. Use Horizontal and Vertical logic values to aim.

OperationalDetails.title: Signal Strength vs Angle
OperationalDetails.description: Same efficiency curve as all dishes: 2 = 100%, 5 = 90%, 22.5 = 10%, 45 = 5%, 90 = 1%, 180 = 0.1%. Narrower beam = stronger signal.

OperationalDetails.title: Contact Resolution
OperationalDetails.description: InterrogationProgress shows trader contact resolution (0-100%). MinimumWattsToContact shows power needed, WattsReachingContact shows actual power delivered.

OperationalDetails.title: Landing Pad Assignment
OperationalDetails.description: TargetPadIndex selects which landing pad incoming traders should use. SizeX and SizeZ indicate required pad dimensions for the trader's ship.

OperationalDetails.title: Fastest Dish Movement
OperationalDetails.description: Movement speed of 0.05 (25x faster than Large dish). Both horizontal and vertical speeds are equal, making it the quickest to reposition.

OperationalDetails.title: Rotation Range
OperationalDetails.description: 360 horizontal rotation (lerped from -90 to 270 internal), 90 vertical range (0 to 90). Uses DishTransform.up for forward direction.

OperationalDetails.title: Signal Strength vs Angle
OperationalDetails.description: Same efficiency curve: 2 = 100%, 5 = 90%, 22.5 = 10%, 45 = 5%, 90 = 1%, 180 = 0.1%. Setting controls output wattage (50-200W range).

OperationalDetails.title: Contact Resolution
OperationalDetails.description: SignalStrength shows angle offset to strongest contact (-1 if none). InterrogationProgress shows resolution progress (0-1). Returns -1 values while still resolving.

OperationalDetails.title: Best Contact Filter
OperationalDetails.description: Set BestContactFilter to a specific contact ID to lock onto that trader. Set to -1 to auto-detect the strongest available signal.

NextWeatherHash.description: Hash of next scheduled weather event (0 if no event scheduled).

NextWeatherEventTime.description: Game time in seconds when next weather event will become active.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID for device.

InStorm.description: Weather station is currently within an active storm.

NoStorm.description: Weather station detects clear weather, no storm present.

StormIncoming.description: Weather station detects a storm approaching.

PowerGeneration.description: Current power output. Varies with wind speed (normal: up to 500W, storm: up to 10,000W).

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Power.description: Returns 1 if device has air pressure to operate.

Error.description: Returns 1 if drill has an error (e.g., no air pressure).

Activate.description: Returns 1 when drill is actively mining.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Default.description: Normal mining mode - removes terrain and collects ore. Uses compressed air instead of battery.

Flatten.description: Flattening mode - levels terrain for construction without collecting ore. Uses compressed air.

RatioCarbonDioxide.description: CO2 ratio in canister.

TotalMoles.description: Total gas moles in canister.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Mode0.description: Fill mode - canister accepts gas from connected pipe network when pressure differential allows.

Mode1.description: Empty mode - canister releases gas into connected pipe network when pressure differential allows.

TotalMoles.description: Total liquid moles in canister.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Mode0.description: Fill mode - canister accepts liquid from connected pipe network.

Mode1.description: Empty mode - canister releases liquid into connected pipe network.

TotalMoles.description: Total gas moles in tank.

RatioCarbonDioxide.description: CO2 ratio in tank.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Mode0.description: Fill mode - tank accepts gas from connected pipe network.

Mode1.description: Empty mode - tank releases gas into connected pipe network.

Power.description: Returns 1 if device has battery power.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Cold.description: Cooling mode - removes heat from surrounding atmosphere, lowering temperature. Battery-powered portable unit.

Hot.description: Heating mode - adds heat to surrounding atmosphere, raising temperature. Battery-powered portable unit.

Activate.description: Triggers genetic operation on target plant.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Stabilize.description: Stabilize mode - locks plant genetics, preventing random mutation during harvest. Use to preserve desired traits.

Destabilize.description: Destabilize mode - unlocks plant genetics, enabling mutation and cross-breeding. Use for genetic experimentation.

Setting.description: The hash value being displayed.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Prefab.description: Displays PrefabHash - the item/structure type identifier. Useful for sorting systems.

GasLiquid.description: Displays the gas or liquid type hash of the contents. Useful for atmosphere monitoring.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

None.description: No landing pad status - pad is inactive or not configured.

NoContact.description: No spacecraft contact - pad is ready but no ship is detected.

Moving.description: Spacecraft is moving - ship is approaching, departing, or repositioning.

Holding.description: Spacecraft is holding position - ship is hovering above pad awaiting landing clearance.

Landed.description: Spacecraft has landed - ship is secured on pad, ready for cargo/fuel transfer.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Mode0.description: Impact detonation - charge explodes on collision with terrain or objects.

Mode1.description: Remote detonation - charge arms on placement and waits for remote trigger signal.

Setting.description: Value being transmitted/received.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Passive.description: Passive mode - device only receives signals on its channel, does not broadcast.

Active.description: Active mode - device broadcasts its Setting value on the configured channel.

OperationalDetails.title: Passive Mode Operation
OperationalDetails.description: In Passive mode, use screwdriver to select which device to mirror. The transmitter will read the Setting value from the linked device. Requires power to read values. Reading does NOT require line-of-sight.

OperationalDetails.title: Active Mode Operation
OperationalDetails.description: In Active mode, the transmitter broadcasts its own Setting value. Other transmitters in Passive mode can receive this value if they link to this device via screwdriver.

OperationalDetails.title: Power Requirements
OperationalDetails.description: The transmitter needs power to function. In Passive mode, power is required to read values from the linked device. Without power, the Setting value will not update.

OperationalDetails.title: Linking Process
OperationalDetails.description: Use screwdriver on the transmitter to enter linking mode, then select the target device. The link persists across power cycles. The linked device must have a Setting value to read from.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Mode0.description: Standard composting mode - processes organic matter into fertilizer.

Mode1.description: Alternative composting mode - may affect output ratio or speed.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Mode0.description: Output left - next item routes to left output.

Mode1.description: Output right - next item routes to right output.

ReferenceId.description: Unique reference ID.

Mode0.description: Manual mode - plays notes based on logic input signals.

Mode1.description: Sequence mode - plays pre-programmed musical sequence.

guides.pageDescription: A comprehensive guide for new Stationeers This survival manual covers everything you need to know to survive your first days on an alien world. From basic controls to building your first shelter, from managing your suit to setting up power systems and atmosphere - all the knowledge you need to thrive.

OperationalDetails.title: Part 1: Before You Choke (First 5 Minutes)
OperationalDetails.description: Your journey as a Stationeer begins. You're standing on an alien world with a lander nearby full of supplies. You're already equipped with a spacesuit and tools. Don't panic - you have time.

children.title: Congratulations On Being A Stationeer!
children.description: You've accepted the challenge. Earth needs passionate survivors who will venture out into the dark abyss to create civilization from moon dust. You have self-selected as an adventurer willing to take on unbelievable risks. You're standing on an alien world. There's a lander nearby with crates attached. You're already wearing a spacesuit and holding duct tape. Don't panic. Take a breath (in real life - your character is breathing just fine from their suit - for now). Look around with your mouse. You'll see:
items: Your body - You're in first person by default. Your suit is keeping you alive. If you don't work fast now eventually it'll suffocate you when you run out of air.
The lander - A structure with several crates bolted to it. Everything you need is here.
The terrain - Rock, dust, maybe some ice/ore deposits. This is home now.

children.title: The Clock is Ticking - But You Have Time
children.description: Your suit has limited oxygen, limited battery power, and limited filter life. But here's the good news: you have time. Don't panic and rush. Mistakes from rushing kill more beginners than running out of air. You have roughly 60 minutes of suit supplies if you do nothing. That's plenty of time to get oriented if you stay calm and move efficiently.

children.title: What You're Already Wearing
children.description: Unlike many survival games, you don't spawn naked. You're already fully equipped:

children.title: On Your Body
items: Helmet (Press 1) - On your head, keeping good air in and bad air out. It is locked to begin with (red button)
EVA Suit (Press 3) - Contains: Air canister (5700 kPa oxygen), Waste canister, Large battery cell, 3 CO2 filters
Jetpack (Press 4) - On your back: Propellant canister, Medical pill, Handheld tablet, Mining belt (drill, pickaxe, 20 flares, portable solar panel)
Orange Uniform (Press 5) - Contains: Cereal Bar, Water bottle, Credit card
Toolbelt (Press 6) - Contains: Wrench, Crowbar, Hand drill, Wire cutters, Welder, Screwdriver, Angle grinder, 50 cable coils
In Your Hand - Duct tape for repairing suit damage

children.title: You're Already Set Up
children.description: This is important: you don't need to equip anything. Your suit is working, your filters are filtering, your oxygen is flowing. You're safe for now.

children.title: Basic Controls
children.description: Before we go further, learn these essential controls:

children.title: Hands & Items
items: E - Swap active hand (you have two hands, left and right)
Left Click - Use/interact with what's in your active hand
F - Swap held item with item in inventory slot
Q - Drop held item (hold Q to throw it)
R - Open item in hand, or access its options like splitting if its ore
G - Auto-place held item in a random free inventory slot

children.title: Inventory & Equipment
items: 1-6 keys - Open menus for worn items: 1 = Helmet, 2 = Glasses, 3 = Suit, 4 = Backpack/Jetpack, 5 = Uniform/Belt, 6 = Toolbelt
Hold Alt - Enables mouse cursor for dragging items in inventory windows
L - Toggle suit light on and off

children.title: Understanding Your Suit
children.description: Your suit is keeping you alive. Press 3 to open your suit panel and see your life support controls.

children.title: What You'll See
items: A/C - Air conditioning (heating/cooling). Uses battery power. Your suit uses oxygen from your tank to cool you by sending it to the waste tank.
Filter - Toggle your CO2 filters on/off (leave ON)
Air - Toggle air supply from your tank (leave ON)
Pressure - Your target suit pressure (default is fine, but save oxygen by lowering it to target 30 kPa)
Temperature - Your target temperature (default is fine but save energy by lowering it down as low as 5C, if there is no freezing warning it saves energy)

children.title: How Breathing Works
children.description: The system is a cycle:
steps: Oxygen Tank  Suit Atmosphere  You Breathe  Exhale CO2  Filters Scrub CO2  CO2 & some O2 Goes to Waste Tank
Your air canister (in your suit) feeds oxygen into your suit's internal atmosphere
Your 3 CO2 filters remove the CO2 from your suit atmosphere
The filtered CO2 goes into your waste canister

children.title: When Things Go Wrong
items: Waste tank full (above 4052 kPa): Your filters stop working. CO2 builds up. You suffocate even with oxygen left. Fix: Open your waste canister to vent it

Air tank empty: No new oxygen entering suit. You suffocate when suit atmosphere depletes. Fix: Connect to oxygen source or swap tanks - There is a White Portable Tank in your lander, that contains breathable atmosphere to refill your suit oxygen tank
Filters worn out: Filters have a lifespan (small = 2 hours, medium = 10 hours). When depleted, CO2 builds up. Fix: Swap filters from your supplies
Suit damaged: Pressure leaks. Atmosphere escapes. Fix: Use duct tape (you're holding some!) to repair (Hold duct tape in your hands, and hold down the right mouse button)

children.title: How to Vent Your Waste Tank
children.description: When your waste tank gets too full:
steps: On Moon (vacuum), this just releases CO2 to space. On Mars, it releases to the atmosphere. Either way, it's safe. Best though to release it indoors so you keep the CO2 in your base for early hydroponics - plants need CO2 and the amount released is usually negligible.

children.title: Checking Your Status
children.description: Look at your screen. Several indicators show your status:

children.title: The HUD
items: Bottom central area - Your two hands are shown. Your active hand is highlighted.
Bottom right area - Suit readouts appear here when helmet is on.

Left of your character portrait - Status icons appear here: Helmet icon (locked/unlocked), Pressure warnings, Temperature warnings, Oxygen warnings, Suit damage indicators, Hunger, Thirst, Health damage indicators

children.title: Warning Colors
children.description: Pay attention to warning colors on your HUD to know when something is wrong.

children.title: Cognition Warnings
children.description: If you see cognition warnings, something is very wrong with your atmosphere and you're about to pass out (and probably die). Check your oxygen, filters, and waste tank immediately. Run to safety.

children.title: Checking External Conditions
children.description: Your HUD shows external temperature & pressure in the bottom right. This tells you how hostile the environment is. For more detailed atmospheric readings, use the tablet in your jetpack. One of the crates in your lander has an atmospheric analyzer cartridge you can install to get a readout of atmospheric conditions and composition.

children.title: The Lander and Your Supplies
children.description: Now let's look at what you have to work with.

children.title: The Lander Structure
items: 3 tank mounts (White one has a portable oxygen tank - 7576 kPa = 7.5 MPa)

children.title: Detaching Crates
steps: Equip your wrench from your toolbelt (press 6, then use Alt+mouse or F to swap to hand)
Click on the crate's attachment point
The crate detaches and can be moved

children.title: What's In The Crates/Tanks
children.description: Your starter crates contain everything you need for the first week:

children.title: Portable Tanks
items: White Tank: 7576 kPa of Oxygen (attached to lander)

children.title: Organic Supplies
items: Seeds: Potato, Wheat, Corn, Fern, Tomato, Pumpkin, Soybean, Mushroom, Rice (3 each)

children.title: Don't Leave Things on the Ground
children.description: Important warning: Items left on the ground can be blown away during a storm on most planets. Always put items back in crates or inside your base. Never dump things on the ground and walk away.

children.title: Your First Priority
children.description:
You're equipped. You know the controls. You've seen your supplies. Now what?

Your immediate needs in order:
steps: Shelter - A sealed room protects you from the environment
Air - A pressurized room means you can take off your helmet
Temperature - Too hot or cold and you'll die even with air

children.title: Summary: Your First 5 Minutes
children.description: You should now:
items: Understand you're already equipped and safe (for now)
Know the basic controls (especially 1-6 for equipment, Alt+mouse for inventory)
Understand your suit's breathing system (tank  filters  waste tank)
Know how to check your status and read warnings
Know what's in your lander crates

OperationalDetails.title: Part 2: Shelter (Minutes 5-20)
OperationalDetails.description: You're standing on an alien world. The environment outside is trying to kill you. It's not personal. Your first goal is a sealed room with a door.

children.title: Why You Need Walls
children.description: You're standing on an alien world. The environment outside is trying to kill you: Moon: Vacuum - no atmosphere. It's cold. Mars: Unbreathable CO2 atmosphere, temperature swings, dust storms after day 7 Your suit protects you for now, but it has limited supplies. A sealed shelter gives you:
items: A stable atmosphere you can breathe without consuming suit oxygen
A safe zone to remove your helmet and eat/drink
A place to set up equipment that needs atmosphere

children.title: Planning Your First Base
children.description: Your first goal is a sealed room with a door.

children.title: Location
children.description: Find a relatively flat area near your lander, or if you're adventurous the best view nearby. Consider:
items: Away from hills that might block sunlight for solar panels
Close enough to your supply crates for easy access

children.title: Size Recommendations
children.description: Start small. A 3x3 or 4x4 room is enough for your first shelter. Important: Rooms have a maximum size of 1200 cubes. Larger rooms won't pressurize properly. For a beginner, this won't be an issue - just don't try to enclose a massive area.

children.title: What You'll Build
steps: Later: an airlock system to prevent losing atmosphere

children.title: Understanding the Grid System
children.description: Stationeers uses a grid-based building system. When you enter placement mode: Items snap to grid positions. Some items go on the large grid (walls, frames) and some go on the small grid (doors, consoles, vents, cables). Tip: Watch the in-game tooltips when holding items. They show available placement positions and controls.

children.title: Building Floors
children.description: Floors are optional but give you a surface for the small grid (cables, pipes, devices).

children.title: Steps
steps: Get an Iron Frame from your crate - Use your wrench to detach the crate if needed, then open it and take Iron Frames
Enter placement mode - Hold the Iron Frame in your active hand, press Right-click to enter placement mode. You'll see a ghost outline.
Place the frame - Move around to position it where you want, then Left-click to place it
Complete the floor - Equip your Welder in your active hand, put Iron Sheets in your other hand, press O to turn on the welder
WARNING: The welder will keep emitting toxic gases, heat, and use its fuel if you don't turn it off. Turn it off between uses, especially if in a shelter atmosphere!
Weld - Point at the placed frame and hold left-click to weld. Uses 2 Iron Sheets per frame section

children.title: Important Notes
children.description: Welded frames are walkable platforms but NOT airtight until welded to their final 2/2 welding state. To make airtight floors, you'd add 2 iron sheets total. Iron frames aren't pretty, but they are strong and can essentially hold unlimited pressure. Walls cannot hold unlimited pressure, you can see their limits in the stationpedia.

children.title: Building Walls
children.description: Walls create the airtight barrier around your base.

children.title: What You Need
items: Kit (Iron Wall) - Called Iron Wall Kits (30 in your starter crate)

children.title: Steps
steps: Get an Iron Wall Kit from your crate
Enter placement mode - Right-click with the kit in hand, position it at the edge of your floor area, standing vertically
Place the wall frame - Left-click to place. The wall frame appears but isn't complete yet.
Complete the wall - Take an Iron Sheet in your hand, point at the wall frame, Left-click to attach the sheet. No tools needed for this step.
Repeat around your entire perimeter, leaving ONE gap for your door

children.title: Wall Stats
children.description: Completed iron walls can withstand 200 kPa pressure differential. This is plenty for a normal atmosphere (about 101 kPa inside vs vacuum outside).

children.title: Building a Door
children.description: Your starter kit includes 2 Door Kits. These can become several door types - we'll build a Composite Door which is the standard powered door.

children.title: Steps
steps: Place the Door Kit - Take the Door Kit in hand, Right-click to enter placement mode, position in the gap you left in your walls, Left-click to place. Consider placing the doors with their power/data connectors facing inward to the airlock. So the doors are facing each other.

First construction stage - Equip your Welder in active hand, put a Plastic Sheet in your other hand, turn on welder (press O), point at the door frame and left-click/hold to weld, Turn off welder when done (O)
Second construction stage - Equip your Crowbar in active hand, put a Glass Sheet in your other hand, point at the door and left-click to complete it
Door complete! The door now requires 10 Watts of power to operate. Without power, you can still open it manually (see below).

children.title: Manual Door Operation
children.description: When your door has no power (which it won't at first), you can still use it: 1. Walk up to the door 2. Equip your Crowbar 3. Left-click on the door to force it open/closed The problem: Every time you open the door, your precious atmosphere escapes. On the Moon, it goes straight to vacuum. This is why you'll want an automated airlock - but first, let's check if your room is even sealed.

children.title: Checking for a Seal
children.description: Before pressurizing, verify your room is actually airtight.

children.title: Using the Tablet
steps: It should have an Atmospheric Analyzer Cartridge installed

children.title: Reading the Analyzer
children.description: With the tablet in hand, activate it and check the reading:
items: Shows "World" = Your room is NOT sealed. There's a gap somewhere.
Shows a room number (like Room 1) = Your room IS sealed. You're ready to pressurize.

children.title: Finding Leaks
children.description: If it shows <color=#FFAA00>World</color>, check:
items: Every wall section - make sure all have Iron Sheets attached
The corners - walls need to connect properly
The door - is it fully constructed?

children.title: Summary: Your First Shelter
children.description: You should now have:
items: A sealed room with walls and floor
A door you can operate (manually or with power)
Ideally, an airlock to prevent atmosphere loss
A Portable Generator powering your base with liquid fuel

OperationalDetails.title: Part 3: Not Dying Tonight (Power, Temp, Atmos)
OperationalDetails.description: You have a sealed shelter. Now you need to survive inside it. Three things will kill you if you get them wrong: No Power, Wrong Temperature, and Bad Atmosphere.

children.title: The Three Killers
children.description: You have a sealed shelter. Now you need to survive inside it. Three things will kill you if you get them wrong:
items: No Power - Your doors won't open, your equipment won't run
Wrong Temperature - Too hot or cold and you'll take damage
Bad Atmosphere - Wrong pressure, wrong gases, or no oxygen

children.title: Power Systems
children.description: Everything in your base needs electricity. No power = no survival.

children.title: Understanding Power Basics
children.description: Cables carry electricity:

children.title: Solar Panels
children.description: Your most automatable and simple power source. One Kit (Solar Panel Basic) is in your starter crate. This is the basic solar panel that can't adjust to the angle of the sun. You can plop it down on a frame and hook it up to your power distribution network. Power Output: - Moon: Up to 750W in direct sunlight - Mars: Up to 455W in direct sunlight - Output depends on angle - panels facing the sun directly produce more

children.title: The Solid Fuel Generator (Starter Kit Option)
children.description: Your starter kit includes a Kit (Solid Generator). This burns fuel to produce power - useful for night or emergencies.

children.title: Fuel Types
items: Charcoal - 120 kJ per unit, burns 3 seconds minimum
Solid Fuel - 400 kJ per unit, burns 10 seconds

children.title: Power Output
children.description: Up to 20kW (but requires heavy cables for full output; regular cables limit you to 5kW)

children.title: Battery Charger
children.description: Your starter kit includes a Battery Charger. This charges the small battery cells used in your suit, tablet, and portable devices. Power Draw: - 10W standby - 500W per battery being charged - Maximum 2,500W if charging 5 batteries Charging Times: - Small Battery Cell: ~36 seconds - Large Battery Cell: ~4 minutes 48 seconds

children.title: Temperature Control
children.description: Your body needs to stay within a safe temperature range.

children.title: Portable Air Conditioner (Starter Kit)
children.description: Your starter kit includes a Kit (Portable Air Conditioner). This is your first temperature control option. How it works: - Cold Mode: Removes heat from the room, stores it internally - Hot Mode: Releases stored heat into the room Power: 200W (uses battery cells) - Small Battery: ~1.5 minutes - Large Battery: ~12 minutes Limitations: - Cold mode stops working if room exceeds +30C - Hot mode stops working if room drops below -10C - Internal tank fills up - when it flashes an error, you need to dump the stored heat/cold For beginners: This is temporary. It will keep a small room habitable while you set up better systems. BE CAREFUL. THE COOLANT TANK IS FILLED WITH N2O AND WILL EXPLODE IF IT GETS TOO HOT KILLING YOU AND DESTROYING YOUR BASE!

children.title: Atmosphere Setup
children.description: You need breathable air at the right pressure and temperature.

children.title: What You Need to Breathe
children.description: Oxygen Partial Pressure: - Minimum safe: ~16 kPa oxygen partial pressure - Recommended: ~20 kPa or higher (no warnings) - Warning thresholds: - 16-12 kPa: Yellow "Oxygen Low" warning (no damage) - 12-5 kPa: Red "Oxygen Critical" warning (no damage yet) - Below 5 kPa: You're suffocating What is Partial Pressure? It's the portion of total pressure from one specific gas. Example: If your room has 100 kPa total pressure and is 20% oxygen: - Oxygen partial pressure = 100 0.20 = 20 kPa (breathable) Example: If your room has 50 kPa total and is 20% oxygen: - Oxygen partial pressure = 50 0.20 = 10 kPa (critical warning)

children.title: Filling your Suit Oxygen Tank
children.description: Your lander has a Portable Tank with 7576 kPa of pure oxygen. You can use this directly. It's best though to use this tank to fill your suit oxygen tank until you can get a system up to sustainably filter oxygen from other gases and put it in your suit tank. You can also use dirty air (oxygen, nitrogen etc.) in your suit tank if you apply the correct filters. An easy way to get more air in your tank is to use a canister filler with an active vent and suck in base air carefully until you fill the tank. For now, stick with using your Portable Oxygen Tank's canister slot to fill your oxygen tank.

children.title: CO2, Pollutant, Volatiles Buildup
children.description: When humans breathe, they exhale CO2. Over time, CO2 builds up in your base. This is normally ok because you can use it to feed your plants and it has to be very high to cause poisoning. This is not true for Pollutant and Volatiles, so you want to filter those if any are present. Check your room air makeup with your atmos cartridge in your tablet. Option 1: Portable Scrubber (Starter Kit) Your kit includes a Kit (Portable Scrubber). How it works: 1. Build the scrubber 2. Insert the Pollutant Filter & Volatiles Filter in the back. They came with your scrubber. 3. Power with battery (uses 20.5W) 4. It absorbs Volatiles & Pollutant from the room air When the internal tank fills (8106 kPa), the scrubber flashes an error. You need to empty it: - Bring it outside - Pull the lever to vent (releases any gases it is filtering)

children.title: Checking Your Atmosphere
children.description: Use your Tablet with Atmospheric Analyzer Cartridge: - Shows temperature - Shows pressure - Shows gas composition (percentages) Calculate partial pressure: Total Pressure Gas Percentage = Partial Pressure

children.title: Suit Management
children.description: While you're setting up your base, you're still relying on your suit. Once you've got an atmosphere properly set up you can open it.

children.title: Refilling Your Suit Oxygen
children.description: Method 1: Room Atmosphere If your base has breathable atmosphere: 1. Open your helmet (press I - but only if atmosphere is safe!) 2. Your suit will equalize with room atmosphere 3. Close helmet when leaving Method 2: Direct from Portable Tank 1. Take a Gas Canister (small canister, not the portable tank) 2. Place it in the striped slot on top of the Portable Tank 3. The canister fills with oxygen 4. Take the canister 5. Open your suit inventory (press 3) 6. Replace your air canister with the full one

children.title: Emptying Your Waste Tank
children.description: Your suit's waste tank collects filtered CO2. When it exceeds ~4052 kPa, your filters stop working. Vent this inside your base so you can feed your plants! To vent: 1. Press 3 to open suit panel 2. Find your waste canister 3. Click on it, select Open 4. CO2 vents to atmosphere

children.title: Filter Lifespan
children.description:
Your suit's CO2 filters have limited life:

- Small Filter: 2 hours
- Medium Filter: 10 hours
- Large Filter: 40 hours

Filters only degrade when actively filtering CO2. Check your filter status regularly.

children.title: Food and Water
children.description: You won't starve in the first hour, but you need to plan ahead.

children.title: Starting Supplies
items: In your Orange Uniform (on your body): Cereal Bar, Water Bottle
In Survival Supplies crate: 1 Water Bottle Box (4 bottles), 2 Cereal Bar Boxes (6 bars each)
In Your Lander: 1 Water Bottle Bag (4 Bottles), 1 Cereal Bar Bag (6 Bars)

children.title: Eating and Drinking
children.description: On easier difficulties: You can consume through your suit. On Normal+ difficulties: You must open your helmet to eat/drink - meaning you need breathable atmosphere first. To consume: 1. Hold the food/water in your hand 2. Open your helmet (if required by difficulty) 3. Left-click to consume

children.title: Hunger and Thirst Mechanics
children.description: You can let health drop from hunger/thirst and recover later - you don't need to eat constantly. If your health bar gets down to 0 you die. Rough timeline (Stationeer difficulty): - Starting oxygen: More than a week - Starting water: About a week - Starting food: About a week

children.title: Your First Night Checklist
children.description: Before the sun sets (or before you run out of suit supplies):

children.title: Minimum Viable Base
items: Some atmosphere inside (oxygen from portable tank)
Temperature above 0C (use Portable AC if needed)

children.title: Better Setup
items: Solid Fuel Generator as backup power
Battery Charger keeping your suit batteries full
Enough pressure (30+ kPa pure O2, or 100 kPa mixed)

children.title: Before Opening Your Helmet
items: Check oxygen: At least 20 kPa partial pressure

children.title: Summary
children.description: You now know how to survive your first night.

children.title: Atmosphere
items: Need ~20 kPa oxygen partial pressure minimum
30 kPa pure O2 works for early game
Watch for CO2 buildup - use Portable Scrubber

children.title: Suit
items: Refill oxygen before it runs out
Vent waste tank when it fills

children.title: Food/Water
items: You have about a week of supplies

OperationalDetails.title: Quick Reference
OperationalDetails.description: Key specifications and common values.

OperationalDetails.title: Mode Details
OperationalDetails.description: The sensor has three modes that change what SolarAngle outputs.

children.title: Default Mode (0)
children.description: Outputs angle between sensor's forward direction and sun. Good for simple day/night detection.

children.title: Horizontal Mode (1)
children.description: Outputs only the sun's horizontal (azimuth) angle. Range: 0-360. Good for single-axis horizontal tracking.

children.title: Vertical Mode (2)
children.description: Outputs only the sun's vertical (elevation) angle. Good for single-axis vertical tracking.

OperationalDetails.title: Solar Panel Tracking
OperationalDetails.description: For solar panel tracking, use the Horizontal and Vertical logic outputs directly.

children.title: The Orientation Problem
children.description: Critical: The daylight sensor and solar panel must have matching orientations for direct angle copying to work.
items: Same Orientation: Both on same surface, same direction - angles can be copied directly
Different Orientation: Angles will be offset - need Math Unit or reposition sensor

children.title: Basic Tracking Setup
children.description: Hardware needed:
items: 2x Logic Writer (or 2x Batch Writer for multiple panels)

children.title: Logic Writer Config
items: Writer #1: Input: Sensor Horizontal Output: Panel Horizontal
Writer #2: Input: Sensor Vertical Output: Panel Vertical

children.title: IC10 Basic Tracking
children.description:
Simple IC10 code:

<color=#FFAA00>alias Sensor d0</color>
<color=#FFAA00>alias Panel d1</color>

main:
  l r0 Sensor Horizontal
  l r1 Sensor Vertical
  s Panel Horizontal r0
  s Panel Vertical r1
  yield
  j main

children.title: IC10 Batch Tracking
children.description:
For multiple panels:

<color=#FFAA00>alias Sensor d0</color>
<color=#FFAA00>define PanelHash HASH("StructureSolarPanelDual")</color>

main:
  l r0 Sensor Horizontal
  l r1 Sensor Vertical
  sb PanelHash Horizontal r0
  sb PanelHash Vertical r1
  yield
  j main
