children.title: Offset Correction
children.description:
If sensor and panels have different orientations, add offsets:

<color=#FFAA00>define H_OFFSET 90</color>
add r0 r0 H_OFFSET
mod r0 r0 360

children.title: Day/Night Light Control
children.description: Turn lights on at night: l r0 Sensor Activate seqz r0 r0 (invert for lights) sb LightHash On r0

OperationalDetails.title: Placement Guidelines
OperationalDetails.description: Optimal sensor placement:
items: Unobstructed view - Sensor needs line-of-sight to sun
Match panel orientation - Easiest if same direction as panels
Accessible for wiring - Data port needs cable connection

OperationalDetails.title: Troubleshooting
OperationalDetails.description: Common issues and solutions.

children.title: No Sunlight Detection
items: Activate = 0 during day: Sensor blocked or inside - move outside

children.title: Tracking Issues
items: Panels aim wrong: Orientation mismatch - add angle offsets
Panels oscillate: Update too fast - add yield/sleep
Panels don't move: No data connection - check cables

guides.pageDescription: A beginner-friendly guide covering power generation, storage, and distribution from early game through mid game. The Golden Rule: If machines demand more power than cables can handle, cables fry randomly. This is the #1 cause of 'why did my base stop working?'

OperationalDetails.title: Power Basics
OperationalDetails.description: Understanding power flow in Stationeers.

children.title: Basic Power Flow
children.description:
Generator/Solar  Heavy Cable  Transformer/APC  Normal Cable  Devices

Never connect high-power sources directly to normal cables without protection.

children.title: Protection Options
items: Fuse: Blows instead of random cables (5kW, 100kW, 500kW variants)
APC: Limits + battery buffer for variable loads

OperationalDetails.title: Solar Panels
OperationalDetails.description: Free power from the sun.

children.title: Manual Setup
items: Place Solar Panel on large grid
Use wrench to aim - check 'Ratio' value (1.0 = perfect)

children.title: Automated Tracking
children.description: Use Daylight Sensor + Logic Writers to automatically aim panels at sun. See the Daylight Sensor Guide for details.

OperationalDetails.title: Wind Turbines
OperationalDetails.description: Power from planetary atmospheres.

children.title: Upright Wind Turbine
children.description: Early game option - no steel required.

children.title: Large Wind Turbine
children.description: Higher output but requires steel.

children.title: Storm Protection
children.description: CRITICAL: Large turbines can spike to 20kW during storms.

OperationalDetails.title: Solid Fuel Generator
OperationalDetails.description: Backup/emergency power that burns fuel.

children.title: Fuel Types
items: Solid Fuel: 10 sec burn, 400 kJ, best efficiency

children.title: When to Use
items: Good for: Night backup, emergencies, early game, temporary high-power needs
Not good for: Primary power (wastes fuel), unattended operation

OperationalDetails.title: Batteries & APCs
OperationalDetails.description: Power storage and distribution.

children.title: Battery Placement
children.description: Keep batteries in pressurized, warm rooms to minimize drain. A battery in vacuum loses 50W constantly.

children.title: Area Power Controller (APC)
children.description: Creates isolated subnetworks with battery backup.

OperationalDetails.title: Early Game Layout
OperationalDetails.description:
Recommended power structure:

Solar Panels (Heavy Cable)  Station Battery  APC  Normal Cable  Devices
items: Transformer limits draw on branch circuits

OperationalDetails.title: Troubleshooting
OperationalDetails.description: Common power problems.

children.title: Cable Problems
items: Random cables burning: Exceeded cable limit - add transformer/fuse
Can't find burnt cable: Use Cable Analyzer, check near high-draw devices
Burns during storms: Wind turbine spike - add transformer

children.title: No Power Output
items: Solar shows 0W: No glass sheet or not aimed at sun
Wind turbine 0W: Must be outside in atmosphere
Generator not running: No fuel or not activated

children.title: Battery Issues
items: Drains fast overnight: Too much passive drain - move to pressurized room
Not charging: Output exceeds input - add more generation

guides.pageDescription:
A comprehensive guide to building and configuring automated airlocks in Stationeers.

An airlock is a chamber between two doors that prevents atmosphere from escaping when you enter or exit your base.

OperationalDetails.title: Airlock Types
OperationalDetails.description: Stationeers provides two circuitboard types:

children.title: When to Use Which
items: Advanced: Mars (CO2 atmos), Europa (thin atmos), Loulan (high pressure)

OperationalDetails.title: Components Required
OperationalDetails.description: What you need to build an airlock.

OperationalDetails.title: Door Types
items: Composite Door: 10W, 300 kPa rating, from starter kit

OperationalDetails.title: Basic Airlock Setup
OperationalDetails.description: Step-by-step for vacuum airlocks.

children.title: Step 1: Build Chamber
children.description: Create a small enclosed room (2x1 or 3x1 is enough) with airtight walls and openings for two doors.

children.title: Step 2: Install Doors
children.description: IMPORTANT before configuration:

children.title: Step 3: Piping
children.description:
Connect Active Vent to base atmosphere:

[Base] - [Passive Vent] - [Pipe] - [Active Vent in Airlock]

children.title: Step 4: Wire Everything
children.description: All devices on same cable network:

children.title: Step 5: Configure Console
children.description: Use Screwdriver on console side screw.

OperationalDetails.title: Advanced Airlock Setup
OperationalDetails.description: For atmosphere-to-atmosphere cycling.

children.title: Key Difference
children.description: You need TWO separate pipe networks that must NOT connect:
items: Interior network: Connects to your base atmosphere

OperationalDetails.title: Common Problems
OperationalDetails.description: Troubleshooting airlock issues.

children.title: ERROR IN CONFIG
items: Cause: Door states wrong, wrong order, or corrupted config
Fix: Exterior door OPEN, interior CLOSED, select exterior FIRST
Reset: Screwdriver on circuitboard to factory reset

children.title: Doors Stay Locked
items: Cause: No power, not networked, incomplete config
Fix: Verify power, check cables, reset and reconfigure

children.title: Locked Out After Power Loss
items: Cause: Circuitboard locks doors when powered, lock persists
Prevention: Use APC with battery for airlock

OperationalDetails.title: Best Practices
items: Always use APC with battery - Prevents lockouts
Label everything - Interior Door, Exterior Door, etc.
Set door states before config - Exterior OPEN, Interior CLOSED
Select exterior first - First door = exterior portal

OperationalDetails.title: Quick Reference
OperationalDetails.description: Configuration order summary:

guides.pageDescription: From emergency cooling to full climate control systems. WARNING: Read the first section carefully - your starter kit contains a potential bomb!

OperationalDetails.title: STOP - Read This First
OperationalDetails.description: Your Starter Kit Contains a Bomb The Liquid Nitrogen Canister that comes with your Kit (Portable Air Conditioner) is wrapped in insulation. The moment you unwrap it, a countdown to explosion begins.

children.title: What Happens
steps: You unwrap the canister - insulation disappears
As it warms, it phase-changes to gas
Gas takes up FAR more volume than liquid

children.title: This Happens No Matter What
items: Insert into Portable AC: Slows warming Still explodes
Actually use it for cooling: Phase change Overpressure Explodes

children.title: The Safe Solution
children.description: Do not unwrap the canister until you have built:
items: A pipe network with adequate tank capacity
A Portables Connector to link the Portable AC to pipes
When connected, phase-changing nitrogen vents safely into pipes

OperationalDetails.title: Portable Air Conditioner
OperationalDetails.description: Your first temperature control option. Battery-powered, can both heat and cool.

children.title: How It Works
items: Cold Mode: Pulls heat OUT of room, stores internally
Hot Mode: Releases stored heat INTO room

children.title: Operating Limits
items: Hot Mode: Errors if room drops below -10C

children.title: Correct Setup
children.description: Connect to pipe network via Portables Connector:
steps: Run pipes from Connector to outside
Pressurize with 50-100 kPa of any gas
Use Wrench on Portable AC to attach
NOW unwrap and insert the nitrogen canister

OperationalDetails.title: Wall-Mounted Air Conditioner
OperationalDetails.description: Proper climate control with built-in thermostat. Requires crafting.

children.title: Ports
items: Waste: Coolant loop - carries away excess heat

children.title: Efficiency Factors
children.description: The AC has THREE efficiency factors that multiply together. If ANY is near zero, the AC does almost nothing.

children.title: Quick Rules
items: Pressure: Keep room AND waste loop above 100 kPa
Temperature Diff: Keep under 50C between Input and Waste
Rule of thumb: One AC per 50C of cooling/heating needed

OperationalDetails.title: Basic Room Cooling Setup
OperationalDetails.description: Reference build using exterior radiators.

children.title: Room Air Loop
children.description:
[Room]  Passive Vent  AC Output
[Room]  Passive Vent  AC Input

Room air circulates through the AC.

children.title: Waste Loop
children.description:
AC Waste  Pipes  Radiators  Pipes  back to AC Waste

Closed loop, place radiators outside. Fill with CO2 or Pollutants (200-500 kPa).

OperationalDetails.title: Gas Choice for Coolant
items: Oxygen: Good - but don't waste your O2 on coolant

children.title: Low Efficiency
items: Radiators cold but low efficiency: Room pressure below 100 kPa
0% OTE: Waste loop temp wrong for mode (cooling needs colder waste)
AC runs but no change: Check all three efficiencies

children.title: Portable AC Issues
items: Canister exploded: Wasn't connected to pipe network
Error flashing: Internal tank full OR room temp outside operating range

OperationalDetails.title: Summary
items: Portable AC: Connect to pipes BEFORE using, canister WILL explode otherwise
Wall AC: Three efficiency factors - pressure, temp differential, operating temp
Coolant: Use CO2 or Pollutants in waste loops

OperationalDetails.title: The Three Furnace Types
OperationalDetails.description: Arc Furnace Furnace (Standard) Advanced Furnace
items: Best for: Iron, Gold, Copper, Silicon, Nickel, Cobalt, Lead ingots
Use when: You need lots of basic ingots and have power to spare
Combustion-based, requires fuel gas (H2 + O2 from ice)
This is what most players build first
Makes: Steel, Solder, Electrum, Invar, Constantan
Use when: You need alloys for construction and electronics
Higher pressure tolerance (max 60 MPa before explosion)
Makes: Stellite, Inconel, Hastelloy, Astroloy, Waspaloy
Use when: Building rockets or endgame equipment

OperationalDetails.title: Key Concept
OperationalDetails.description: The furnace combines whatever's inside when temperature and pressure conditions are met. YOU must load the correct ratios before igniting. Ratios must be exact - 3:1 means exactly 3:1, not approximately.

OperationalDetails.title: Safety Warning
OperationalDetails.description: All furnaces radiate heat into surrounding atmosphere. Your base WILL heat up. Plan for ventilation or isolate your smelting area.

OperationalDetails.title: Recipe (Verified)
OperationalDetails.description: Conditions:
items: Temperature: 900 K - 100 kK (wide range, easy to hit)
Pressure: 1 - 100 MPa (wide range, easy to hit)

OperationalDetails.title: What You Need
items: Iron and Coal in exact 3:1 ratio
2 Volatiles Ice + 1 Oxite Ice (provides H2 fuel + O2 oxidizer)

OperationalDetails.title: The Process
steps: Load ores FIRST - Iron and Coal in 3:1 ratio (e.g., 75 Iron + 25 Coal)
Wait - furnace will reach ~1050K and ~6.2 MPa
When "Output: Steel" shows and temp/pressure stabilize, open and collect

OperationalDetails.title: Why It Works
items: Volatiles ice releases H2 (hydrogen) - the fuel
Oxite ice releases O2 (oxygen) - the oxidizer
Combustion creates heat AND pressure simultaneously
Steel's wide acceptable ranges (900K+, 1 MPa+) make it forgiving

cells: Check the activation port, use welder or igniter

OperationalDetails.title: Solder
OperationalDetails.description: For electronics, circuits, cables Warning: Temperature has a MAX of 550K. Too hot = failure. This is the only alloy where you might need to COOL the furnace or use less ice.

OperationalDetails.title: Electrum
OperationalDetails.description: For advanced electronics, some sensors Warning: Pressure has a narrow window (0.8-2.4 MPa). Too much ice will overshoot. Use minimal ice - 1 Volatiles + 1 Oxite or less.

OperationalDetails.title: Invar
OperationalDetails.description: For precision instruments, advanced frames Warning: BOTH windows are narrow. Temperature must be 1.2-1.5 kK AND pressure must be 18-20 MPa. This is one of the hardest basic alloys. You need significant ice but precise amounts.

OperationalDetails.title: Constantan
OperationalDetails.description: For heating elements, thermocouples Notes: High minimum pressure (20 MPa) but wide ranges otherwise. Easier than Invar once you get enough pressure.

OperationalDetails.title: Critical Rules for ALL Super-Alloys
steps: Use Advanced Furnace only (60 MPa max capacity)
Recipes use ingots AND ores - some require Steel Ingots, not ores
Monitor pressure/temp constantly - windows can be very narrow
As of 2021, recipes return only 1 ingot per batch

OperationalDetails.title: Stellite
OperationalDetails.description: High-wear applications, cutting tools Notes: Most forgiving super-alloy. Wide temperature range. Good first attempt.

OperationalDetails.title: Inconel
OperationalDetails.description: Heat shields, rocket components Warning: That 0.5 MPa pressure window is brutal. Requires precise pressure control. Monitor closely and vent small amounts to dial in.

OperationalDetails.title: Hastelloy
OperationalDetails.description: Corrosion-resistant components Warning: Temperature window is only 50K (950-1000K). Pressure window is reasonable at 5 MPa range.

OperationalDetails.title: Astroloy
OperationalDetails.description: Aerospace, high-stress applications Notes: Requires Steel Ingots (smelt steel first). 10 MPa pressure window is workable. Wide temp range.

OperationalDetails.title: Waspaloy
OperationalDetails.description: Ultimate high-temp applications Notes: Highest pressure requirement (50+ MPa) but widest pressure window. Temperature is counterintuitively LOW - don't overheat!

OperationalDetails.title: Explosion Prevention
OperationalDetails.description: Prevention Rules:
items: Never overload ice - 3 Volatiles + 2 Oxite is usually the safe max

OperationalDetails.title: Heat Management
OperationalDetails.description: Furnaces radiate heat into surrounding atmosphere. A 1000K furnace WILL cook your base and kill you. Solutions:
steps: Isolate it - Put furnace in separate room with airlock, vent to space after each smelt
Vacuum smelting - No atmosphere = no heat transfer to base
Active cooling - Wall coolers + radiators if you want it indoors
Distance - Further from living space = more time to react

cells: No fuel gas or no O2
Check ice loaded, try more Oxite
Got base ingots instead of alloy
Check BOTH min AND max values
Alloy won't form despite correct values
Some alloys have narrow windows - check maximums

OperationalDetails.title: Emergency Procedures
OperationalDetails.description: Overheating base: Pressure climbing dangerously:
items: Seal furnace room from living area
Open furnace to vent (loses heat too)
Or use attached pipe to bleed off gas gradually

OperationalDetails.title: Ice Only Recipes
OperationalDetails.description: These recipes use ice chunks only for fuel. Load the ices first and ignite, then immediately add the ores. No wait time needed. Instructions: 1. Load ice first 2. Press Activate button 3. Add ingredients immediately 4. Wait for "will produce" to appear 5. Pull the handle to eject
items: *** = Use Ingots instead of raw ores to prevent extra gas production

OperationalDetails.title: Gaseous Fuel Recipes
OperationalDetails.description: These recipes use pre-mixed fuel gas (2:1 Volatiles:Oxygen ratio) pumped from canisters. Requires an ice crusher or gas mixing setup. Making Fuel: Mix 2 Volatiles ice + 1 Oxite ice in an Ice Crusher to get a ~1.95:1 H2:O2 ratio (close enough to 2:1). Instructions: 1. Pump fuel gas into furnace 2. Press Activate to ignite 3. Add ingredients immediately 4. Wait for "will produce" 5. Pull handle to eject

cells: 205 mol H2 + 105 mol O2 + 538 mol CO2

items: Note: Invar requires CO2 as a pressurant to reach the narrow pressure window
Other pressurants (N2, Pollutant) may work but results may vary

OperationalDetails.title: Key Notes
OperationalDetails.description: Data verified from Stationeers Wiki (January 2025). Game updates may change values - if a recipe fails, check the in-game Stationpedia (F1).
items: Check BOTH min AND max - Many alloys fail from exceeding maximums
Super-alloys return 1 ingot per batch (as of 2021 update)
Inconel and Astroloy need Steel Ingots - smelt steel first

OperationalDetails.title: Temperature Tolerance (From Lungs.cs)
OperationalDetails.description: Calculation: <color=#88FF88>ZeroDegrees (273.15K)  offset</color>

OperationalDetails.title: Ideal Human Atmosphere
OperationalDetails.description: Safe Ranges:
items: Pressure: 50-200 kPa total (too high = suit warning)

OperationalDetails.title: Atmospheric Requirements (From LungsZrilian.cs)
OperationalDetails.description: Critical: Volatiles (H2) are NOT toxic to Zrilians - they breathe it! But Volatiles ARE toxic to Humans.

cells: Uses same threshold as human O2

OperationalDetails.title: Temperature Tolerance (From LungsZrilian.cs)
OperationalDetails.description: Zrilians have wider temperature tolerance than Humans:

OperationalDetails.title: Ideal Zrilian Atmosphere
OperationalDetails.description: Safe Ranges:

OperationalDetails.description: *The UI still shows the O2 icon, but Zrilians need Volatiles, not Oxygen.

OperationalDetails.title: Atmospheric Requirements
OperationalDetails.description: Robots have no breathing requirements:

OperationalDetails.title: Temperature Tolerance
OperationalDetails.description: Robots have wider temperature tolerance than organic species, but still take damage from extreme temperatures. Exact limits depend on specific robot type.

OperationalDetails.title: Power Requirements
OperationalDetails.description: Instead of food/water, robots need:
items: Some robots can recharge from power networks

OperationalDetails.title: Starvation & Dehydration Damage
OperationalDetails.description: When Nutrition or Hydration reaches 0:
items: Healing occurs when fed/hydrated if damage < certain threshold

OperationalDetails.title: Food Sources

OperationalDetails.title: The Human-Zrilian Problem
OperationalDetails.description: Humans need: O2 (breathe) + no Volatiles (toxic) Zrilians need: Volatiles (breathe) + no Pollutant (toxic) These requirements are mutually exclusive:
items: Volatiles are life support for Zrilians
They cannot share the same air

OperationalDetails.title: Solutions for Multi-Species Bases
items: Everyone wears suits with appropriate tanks

OperationalDetails.title: Suit Requirements
OperationalDetails.description: Human Suits: Zrilian Suits:

OperationalDetails.title: Human First Minutes
steps: Find/build shelter before suit runs out
Set up O2 supply (Oxite ice  furnace/electrolyzer)
Remove Volatiles from atmosphere (vent or filter)

OperationalDetails.title: Zrilian First Minutes
steps: Find/build shelter before suit runs out
Set up Volatiles supply (Volatiles ice  furnace/electrolyzer)

OperationalDetails.title: Gas Sources
OperationalDetails.description: Data extracted from decompiled game files: Lungs.cs, LungsZrilian.cs, Entity.cs, SpeciesClass.cs, Chemistry.cs. Values are authoritative as of game version current to January 2026.

genericDescriptions.SortingClass: Sorting class for the item in slot.
genericDescriptions.Class: Class type hash of item in slot.
genericDescriptions.ChargeRatio: Charge as ratio of maximum capacity (0-1).
genericDescriptions.Charge: Current charge level of internal battery or power storage.
genericDescriptions.Occupied: Returns 1 if slot contains an item, 0 if empty.
genericDescriptions.Damage: Damage level of item in slot (0=pristine, 1=destroyed).
genericDescriptions.OccupantHash: PrefabHash of item in slot, or 0 if empty.
genericDescriptions.Quantity: Number of items in device or stack quantity.
genericDescriptions.ReferenceId: Unique reference ID for this device instance.
genericDescriptions.Efficiency: Efficiency rating of the item in the slot (0-1 ratio).
genericDescriptions.Health: Current health value of the item in the slot.
genericDescriptions.Growth: Growth progress of a plant (used in hydroponics/agriculture).
genericDescriptions.PressureWaste: Waste gas pressure in the slot (used in suit slots).
genericDescriptions.PressureAir: Air pressure in the slot (used in suit backpack slots).
genericDescriptions.Mature: Whether the plant in the slot is mature (1=mature, 0=growing).
genericDescriptions.Seeding: Whether the plant in the slot is producing seeds (1=seeding).
genericDescriptions.LineNumber: Current line number being executed (for IC chips in slots).
genericDescriptions.Volume: The internal volume capacity of this device or container in liters. This determines how much gas or liquid it can hold. Larger volume = more stuff fits. Use this with Moles Per Litre to calculate how many moles a container can hold at a given pressure and temperature.
genericDescriptions.On: Device on/off state. Can be set via logic.
genericDescriptions.Lock: Locks device interaction when set to 1.
genericDescriptions.FilterType: Filter type hash of the item in slot (for filter cartridges).
genericDescriptions.HarvestedHash: Prefab hash of what will be harvested from the plant.
genericDescriptions.Mode: Current operating mode of the device. Values are device-specific.
genericDescriptions.MaturityRatio: Maturity progress ratio of the plant (0-1).
genericDescriptions.SeedingRatio: Seeding progress ratio of the plant (0-1).
genericDescriptions.FreeSlots: Number of free slots available in the container item.
genericDescriptions.TotalSlots: Total number of slots in the container item.
genericDescriptions.Tier One: Base manufacturing tier. Standard speed and efficiency. Available by default on all printers.
genericDescriptions.Tier Two: Upgraded manufacturing tier. Unlocks additional recipes and displays recipe icon on the printer. Apply a Printer Mod upgrade kit to reach this tier.
genericDescriptions.Tier Three: Advanced manufacturing tier. Highest capability with fastest production and most recipe options. Apply a second Printer Mod upgrade kit to reach this tier.

genericDescriptions.RatioLiquidNitrousOxideInput2: Ratio of liquid N2O at secondary input.
genericDescriptions.RatioLiquidNitrousOxideOutput: Ratio of liquid N2O at output.
genericDescriptions.RatioLiquidNitrousOxideOutput2: Ratio of liquid N2O at secondary output.
genericDescriptions.RatioHydrogen: Ratio of hydrogen gas in contents.
genericDescriptions.RatioLiquidHydrogen: Ratio of liquid hydrogen in contents.
genericDescriptions.RatioPollutedWater: Ratio of polluted water in contents.
genericDescriptions.TargetPadIndex: Index of the target landing pad.
genericDescriptions.MinimumWattsToContact: Minimum power in watts required to establish contact.
genericDescriptions.WattsReachingContact: Current power in watts reaching the contact.
genericDescriptions.ContactTypeId: Type ID of the current contact.
genericDescriptions.BestContactFilter: Filter setting for best contact selection.
genericDescriptions.Pipe Liquid Waste: Outputs waste liquids to the liquid pipe network.
genericDescriptions.Power and Data Input: Combined connection that receives both power and data signals.
genericDescriptions.Pipe Liquid Input: Receives liquids from the liquid pipe network.
genericDescriptions.Chute Input: Receives items from connected chute network.
genericDescriptions.Pipe Waste: Outputs waste gases or byproducts to the pipe network.
genericDescriptions.Power and Data Output: Combined connection that outputs both power and data signals.
genericDescriptions.Data Input: Receives data signals from connected logic devices.
genericDescriptions.Data Output: Sends data signals to connected logic devices.
genericDescriptions.Power Output: Outputs electrical power to the power network.
genericDescriptions.Pipe Liquid Output: Outputs liquids to the liquid pipe network.
genericDescriptions.Landing Pad Input: Connection point for rocket landing pad systems.
genericDescriptions.Pipe Input: Receives gases from the pipe network.
genericDescriptions.Connection: Generic data connection for logic communication between devices.
genericDescriptions.Chute Output: Outputs items to connected chute network.
genericDescriptions.Power Input: Receives electrical power from the power network.
genericDescriptions.Pipe Output: Outputs gases to the pipe network.
genericDescriptions.PrinterInstruction.StackPointer: Sets the instruction stack pointer to the specified address. Valid only at address 63.
genericDescriptions.PrinterInstruction.ExecuteRecipe: Executes the specified recipe if materials are available. Produces the specified quantity of items.
genericDescriptions.PrinterInstruction.WaitUntilNextValid: Pauses execution until the next recipe instruction becomes valid (has required materials).
genericDescriptions.PrinterInstruction.JumpIfNextInvalid: Jumps to the specified address if the next recipe cannot be executed due to missing materials.
genericDescriptions.PrinterInstruction.JumpToAddress: Unconditionally jumps to the specified instruction address.
genericDescriptions.PrinterInstruction.EjectReagent: Ejects the specified reagent from the printer by its hash.
genericDescriptions.PrinterInstruction.EjectAllReagents: Ejects all reagents from the printer.
genericDescriptions.PrinterInstruction.MissingRecipeReagent: OUTPUT DATA: Contains missing reagent info for current recipe. Valid only at addresses 54-62 (read-only).
genericDescriptions.SorterInstruction.FilterPrefabHashEquals: Filter items where PrefabHash equals the specified value. Only matching items pass through.
genericDescriptions.SorterInstruction.FilterPrefabHashNotEqu: Filter items where PrefabHash does NOT equal the specified value. Non-matching items pass through.
genericDescriptions.SorterInstruction.FilterSortingClassComp: Filter items by comparing their SortingClass. Condition: 0=Equals, 1=Greater, 2=Less, 3=NotEquals.
genericDescriptions.SorterInstruction.FilterSlotTypeCompare: Filter items by comparing their SlotType. Condition: 0=Equals, 1=Greater, 2=Less, 3=NotEquals.
genericDescriptions.SorterInstruction.FilterQuantityCompare: Filter items by comparing their stack quantity. Condition: 0=Equals, 1=Greater, 2=Less, 3=NotEquals.
genericDescriptions.SorterInstruction.LimitNextExecutionByCo: Limits the next filter instruction to only process the specified number of items (decrements on match).
genericDescriptions.RocketAvionicsInstruction.StackPointer: Sets the avionics instruction stack pointer. Valid only at address 63.
genericDescriptions.RocketAvionicsInstruction.JumpToAddress: Jumps to the specified instruction address. Valid at addresses 0-53.
genericDescriptions.RocketAvionicsInstruction.ChildResourceS: OUTPUT DATA: Contains child resource mining site information. Valid at addresses 54-62 (read-only).
genericDescriptions.RocketAvionicsInstruction.ChildSurveySit: OUTPUT DATA: Contains child survey site information for scanning operations. Valid at addresses 54-62 (read-only).
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.WriteTraderData: Writes trader contact data to the stack at the specified index.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.StrongestContactIdHash: Contains the ID hash of the strongest trader contact signal.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.StrongestContactMetaDa: Returns metadata about the strongest trader contact including shuttle type and tier.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.StrongestContactSignal: Returns signal strength data for the strongest trader contact.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.WriteTraderBuyData: Writes a buy order to purchase items from the trader.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.WriteTraderSellData: Writes a sell order to sell items to the trader.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.TraderBuyThingData: Specifies an item to buy from the trader by PrefabHash.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.TraderBuyThingChildDat: Specifies a child item to buy (item contained within another item).
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.TraderBuyGasData: Specifies gas to purchase from the trader using gas type bitflags.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.TraderSellThingData: Specifies an item to sell to the trader by PrefabHash.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.TraderSellGasData: Specifies gas to sell to the trader using gas type bitflags.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.TraderSellThingChildDa: Specifies a child item to sell (item contained within another item).
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.FilterPrefabHashEquals: Filter trade items where PrefabHash equals the specified value.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.FilterPrefabHashNotEqu: Filter trade items where PrefabHash does NOT equal the specified value.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.FilterSortingClassComp: Filter trade items by comparing their SortingClass.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.FilterQuantityCompare: Filter trade items by comparing their quantity.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.FilterGasContains: Filter for items/containers that contain the specified gas types.
genericDescriptions.TraderInstruction.FilterGasNotContains: Filter for items/containers that do NOT contain the specified gas types.
genericDescriptions.OccupancyInstruction.Entity: Detects entity occupancy (players, NPCs, creatures in the sensor area).
genericDescriptions.OccupancyInstruction.Inventory: Detects inventory occupancy (items in slots within the sensor area).
genericDescriptions.CelestialTrackerInstruction.BodyOrientat: Celestial body orientation data. Auto-populated by device with azimuth and elevation in deci-degrees.
genericDescriptions.Flashpoint: The temperature this material needs to reach to catch fire from nearby flames. If there's already a fire burning in the atmosphere and this material gets hot enough, it will ignite. Lower atmospheric pressure makes it harder to ignite (needs higher temperature). Think of it like paper near a campfire - it won't burn until it's hot enough.
genericDescriptions.Autoignition: The temperature at which this material will spontaneously burst into flames WITHOUT any spark or nearby fire. CRITICAL: The atmosphere must also have enough total energy (>10M joules). What does 10M joules mean? Roughly 20+ moles of gas at 500K, or 100+ moles at room temperature. In practice: thin atmospheres WON'T autoignite even when hot enough - you need thick, hot gas. This is why things don't randomly combust in space despite being at high temperature.
genericDescriptions.Thermal Convection: How fast this object exchanges heat with surrounding gas. Higher number = faster temperature equalization with the atmosphere around it. This is your main cooling/heating mechanism when in atmosphere. The number shown is already multiplied by surface area. Almost useless in vacuum because there's no gas to transfer heat with.
genericDescriptions.Thermal Radiation: How fast this object loses heat to space/surroundings when it's hotter than its environment. This is your ONLY cooling method in vacuum. Higher number = faster cooling. The number shown is already multiplied by surface area. Limited to losing max 50% of total energy per tick to prevent instant freezing.
genericDescriptions.Solar Heating: How much heat this object absorbs from the sun when exposed to direct sunlight. Higher number = faster heating from sun. The number shown is already multiplied by surface area. Effectiveness drops dramatically when already hot (at 450K it's only 50% effective, at 900K only ~9%). Blocked by walls, dust storms reduce it.
genericDescriptions.Max Pressure: The maximum internal pressure this device can handle before it breaks or explodes. Exceeding this will damage or destroy the device. For gas canisters and tanks, this is your safety limit. Always leave safety margin below this value. Standard atmosphere is 101.325 kPa for reference.
genericDescriptions.Base Power: How much power this device constantly uses when turned on and idle (not actively processing). This is your baseline power consumption. Some devices use MORE power when actively working. Calculate your total power needs by adding up all devices' base power draws. 1 Small Battery stores 360,000J (360kW for 1 second).
genericDescriptions.Growth Time: How long it takes this plant to grow from freshly planted to fully mature (harvestable). This is under ideal conditions - actual time can be longer if temperature, atmosphere, or light aren't optimal. Use this to plan your farming schedules and calculate crop yields. Growth Rate logic can speed this up.
genericDescriptions.Specific Heat: How much energy is needed to change this gas's temperature by 1 Kelvin per mole. Think of it as thermal inertia - gases with high specific heat take more energy to heat up but also take longer to cool down. Water vapor has very high specific heat (72), while most other gases are around 20-30.
genericDescriptions.Freeze Temperature: The temperature at which this gas freezes directly into a solid (skipping liquid phase). When gas temperature drops below this and hits a surface, it deposits as ice/frost. This is how you get ice formation on pipes in cold environments. Most gases freeze between 50-90K.
genericDescriptions.Boiling Temperature: The temperature where this liquid boils and turns into gas at normal pressure (101.325 kPa). In the game, this happens when liquids get too hot. Different pressures change the boiling point. Water boils at 373K (100C) at normal pressure but higher in pressure cookers.
genericDescriptions.Max Liquid Temperature: The maximum temperature this substance can reach while still being liquid, regardless of pressure. Above this temperature, it MUST be gas. This is the critical point temperature. For most gases in the game, this is well above normal operating temperatures.
genericDescriptions.Min Liquid Pressure: The minimum pressure needed to keep this substance in liquid form at a given temperature. Below this pressure, it will instantly boil into gas (flash boiling). This is why liquids boil in vacuum - there's no pressure to keep them liquid. Critical for handling liquid gases.
genericDescriptions.Latent Heat: How much energy is absorbed when this substance melts (iceliquid) or released when it freezes (liquidice). This is why ice keeps things cold - it absorbs energy as it melts without changing temperature. Water's latent heat is very high (6008 J/mol), making ice excellent for cooling.
genericDescriptions.Moles Per Litre: How many moles of this gas fit in 1 liter of volume at standard pressure (101.325 kPa) and temperature. This tells you how 'dense' the gas is. All gases have roughly similar values (~44 mol/L) because they follow similar physics. Use this to calculate how much gas fits in tanks.
genericDescriptions.Power Storage: How much energy this battery can store in total, measured in joules. Small Battery: 360,000J, Large Battery: 1,800,000J. To calculate runtime: divide this by the power draw in watts. Example: 360,000J  1,000W = 360 seconds (6 minutes) of power.
genericDescriptions.Power Generation: The maximum power this generator can produce per second in watts. Solar panels, gas generators, and other power sources have this rating. Total grid capacity is the sum of all generators. Make sure your total generation exceeds your total consumption or batteries will drain.
genericDescriptions.Nutrition: How many nutrition points this food provides when eaten. Your astronaut needs nutrition to survive. Higher values = more filling. Different foods have different nutrition values - meals are typically more nutritious than raw ingredients. Plan food production to match crew consumption rate.
genericDescriptions.Nutrition Quality: The quality rating of this food item. Higher quality food improves astronaut mood and may provide bonuses. Fresh, properly prepared meals have higher quality than processed or stale food. Quality can degrade over time if food is stored improperly.
genericDescriptions.Mood Bonus: How much this item improves astronaut mood when consumed. Positive mood increases work efficiency and reduces stress. Quality food, recreational items, and comfortable living spaces all provide mood bonuses. Negative mood can lead to reduced productivity.
genericDescriptions.Placeable In Rocket: Whether this item can be placed inside a rocket's cargo bay for transport. Some large structures or devices can't fit in rockets and must be built on-site. Items marked 'Yes' can be loaded into rocket cargo for transport between planets or bases.
genericDescriptions.Rocket Mass: How much this item weighs in the rocket's cargo, measured in kilograms. Total rocket mass (cargo + structure) determines fuel consumption and thrust requirements. Heavier cargo needs more fuel for the same delta-v. Plan your cargo carefully to avoid running out of fuel mid-flight.
